lesson-1.title: Into the Unknown
lesson-1.nodeText: Take the first step of your learning journey into the dark, winding forest of Chess.
lesson-1.panelText:
A figure awoke in a small, poorly-lit glade, nestled deep within a dense, ancient forest. The air was thick with the scent of damp earth and moss, and the soft rustling of leaves was the only sound that broke the heavy silence. The figure had no memory of how they had arrived in this secluded place or even who they were. A dull ache pulsed at the back of their head as they slowly sat up, disoriented.

As they stood, the figure's gaze swept across the glade. The towering trees, their trunks gnarled and twisted with age, reached hundreds of feet into the air, their dense canopies nearly blotting out the sky. The forest seemed to close in around the glade, creating a space that felt both sheltered and suffocating. The only sign of escape was the faintest hint of a path, barely visible beneath the underbrush, leading away from the glade and into the unknown depths of the forest.

Pressing against their chest, the figure felt something cold and metallic beneath their clothing. They reached inside and pulled out a small, metal tag that hung on a thin chain around their neck. The tag was simple, industrial-looking, with a barcode etched into its surface and a single word inscribed beneath it: Sidian. The figure stared at the name, feeling a strange sense of familiarity. It had to be their name. Sidian.

With a mix of apprehension and curiosity, Sidian continued to survey the scene. Their eyes fell upon something else—an object lying half-buried in the soft, loamy soil nearby. It was a book, its leather cover worn and weathered as if it had been exposed to the elements for years. Sidian hesitated for a moment, then crouched down and picked it up, brushing off the dirt and debris that clung to its surface.

Opening the book, Sidian began to leaf through its pages. The text was primarily in English, though the handwriting varied, as if written by different hands over time. But what caught Sidian's attention were the paragraphs interspersed throughout the book, written in a language they couldn’t recognize. The script was ornate, almost runic, with symbols that seemed to pulse with an ancient, hidden power. Alongside the text and the cryptic script were diagrams—a grid, marked with various symbols and figures. It was intricate, almost like a map, but Sidian quickly realized it was something else entirely.

The grid and the symbols seemed to represent some sort of game. Sidian could feel the significance of it, the weight of the history behind those markings. This wasn’t just any game—it felt like something far more profound, a ritual or a test, embedded with the wisdom and conflicts of generations past.

panel-1.panelText: Chess, as well as other disciplines in life, is a deep study. You will face unknowns and you will not always be prepared to handle them. Do you have the courage to take the first step and every step after that?

panel-2.panelText: The geometry of the board is broken down as a grid into files (vertical lines named a-h), and into ranks (horizontal lines named 1-8)

panel-3.panelText: The geometry of the board is broken down as a grid into files (vertical lines named a-h), and into ranks (horizontal lines named 1-8)

panel-4.panelText: Each file and rank pinpoint each of the 64 squares with a name. Highlighted is c2 and g8. Can you name the other square that's highlighted yellow?

panel-5.panelText: When notating what happen in a game, we use [piece letter][to square]. If it's a Pawn, you'll usually see just the name of the square that it's moving to. Here's two more squares that are highlighted. Can you name them?

panel-6.panelText: This is not only a game, you will learn about who you are along the way. Don’t get lost in the tangling branches of variations to find that one tactic. See the full picture. Take in what philosophies are offered and pack them in your bag. The game is an entertaining side effect.

lesson-2.title: Into the Stillness
lesson-2.panelText:
As Sidian continued to inspect the book, the pieces of the puzzle slowly began to fall into place. The diagrams and symbols, which at first seemed cryptic and mysterious, started to take on a more familiar shape—it was the game of Chess. The book was not just a manual for playing the game; it was a comprehensive guide, a deep dive into the history and philosophy of Chess. Each move, each piece, was laden with meaning, representing not just a game, but a reflection of life, strategy, and the eternal conflicts that have shaped history.

The pages were filled with more than just rules and strategies. Interspersed between the technical aspects of the game were rich narratives—stories from a time long past. These tales spoke of powerful wizards and brave warriors, who once clashed on battlefields over politics, religion, and land. But Chess, Sidian discovered, was created as a way to transcend the violence and bloodshed. It was a means to settle disputes with intellect and foresight, a symbolic war fought on a board of sixty-four squares.

The more Sidian read, the more they felt the weight of these stories. The pages seemed to hum with the echoes of those long-dead wizards and warriors, their conflicts now immortalized in the timeless game. It wasn’t just a game; it was a legacy, a way to carry forward the wisdom of those who had come before.

Eager to uncover more, Sidian turned the page. The anticipation grew as they delved deeper into the book, hoping to uncover more secrets and perhaps even the key to their own mysterious past.

panel-1.panelText: Patience is defined as the ability to endure difficult situations. More specifically: delays, frustrations and not getting upset when coming face to face with them.

panel-2.panelText: To make good choices, we need to think before we act. Before that happens we need to give ourselves the time to pause, take a breath, assess what is going on and pick our next move. On the board and in our life.

panel-3.panelText: This is a foundation to build upon for skills that you will pick up in the following lessons. Allow yourself to slow down and have patience to even pause in the face of a problem so you can avoid any mistakes.

lesson-3.title: Into the Objective
lesson-3.nodeText: What are you fighting for? Learn about why Chess is a zero-sum game.
lesson-3.panelText:
Sidian turned the page, expecting to find more of the intricate diagrams and stories that had captivated them so far. But instead, they were met with an empty, blank page. Confused, they frowned and quickly flipped to the next page, only to find it, too, was blank. A sense of unease crept in as they continued to leaf through the book. Page after page, all they found were empty sheets, devoid of any writing or markings.

What was the point of the book? Where had the rest of the pages gone? Was this some kind of trick, or had the knowledge been intentionally hidden? Disappointment mixed with a growing frustration as Sidian reached the end of the book, finding nothing but more blank pages. They closed the book slowly, their thoughts swirling with unanswered questions.

As they stood there, holding the now seemingly useless book, a sudden awareness prickled at the back of their neck. Someone was watching them. Sidian's eyes darted around the glade, scanning the shadows that lurked between the towering trees. And then, they saw it—a figure, partially obscured by the darkness of the forest.

The figure stepped forward, revealing themselves to be a wizard, clad in robes that seemed to blend with the very shadows around them. The wizard's face was partially hidden beneath a hood, but Sidian could feel the intensity of their gaze. Without a word, the wizard raised a hand and beckoned for Sidian to follow.

Hesitation clutched at Sidian's heart. Who was this wizard? What did they want? But despite the uncertainty, curiosity quickly took hold, pushing aside the fear. There was something compelling about the wizard, something that suggested they held the answers Sidian sought.

With a deep breath, Sidian nodded and decided to follow the wizard. Together, they ventured into the depths of the forest, leaving the glade—and the blank book—behind. The trees closed in around them as they walked, their branches intertwining overhead, creating a canopy that seemed to swallow all light. The path ahead was unknown, but Sidian felt a strange pull, a sense that this journey would reveal more than they could have ever imagined.

panel-1.panelText: Take a look the King’s movement now by moving it around the board.

panel-2.panelText: What is the goal here? The normal Chess ending is checkmate. This happens when a King is attacked and there’s no move to stop it from being captured on the next turn.

panel-3.panelText: What is the goal here? The normal Chess ending is checkmate. This happens when a King is attacked and there’s no move to stop it from being captured on the next turn.

panel-4.panelText: There are many types of mating nets.

panel-5.panelText: There are many types of mating nets.

panel-6.panelText: There are many types of mating nets.

panel-7.panelText: There are many types of mating nets.

panel-8.panelText: Other game-ending rules exist. Delivering check a certain number of times, getting a King to a key square, or capturing all pieces. These are considered variants and do not apply in vanilla Chess, only when you and your opponent agree to it.

lesson-4.title: Sliders
lesson-4.nodeText: Learn about the bread and butter of pieces.
lesson-4.panelText:
Sidian trailed behind the wizard, maintaining a cautious distance of about a dozen paces. There was an air of uncertainty that hung between them, thick and palpable. The wizard moved with a calm, deliberate pace, as if he had walked this path countless times before, but Sidian’s steps were hesitant, each one weighed down by apprehension.

As they journeyed deeper into the forest, Sidian’s eyes wandered, taking in the strange, almost surreal surroundings. The forest was ancient, its trees towering and gnarled, their bark worn by the passage of time. But what caught Sidian’s attention were the carvings etched into some of the trees. The intricate symbols were the same as those found in the book, lines and curves forming a script that seemed both foreign and familiar. Sidian paused momentarily to inspect one of these carvings, but the meaning of the symbols remained just out of reach, like a word on the tip of the tongue that refused to be spoken.

With a sigh of resignation, Sidian continued on, following the wizard’s steady pace. The forest seemed to stretch on endlessly, the dense canopy above allowing only the faintest slivers of light to penetrate. The path they walked was narrow, barely more than a trail worn into the underbrush, and the air grew cooler the further they went.

After what felt like hours of walking, the forest suddenly opened up into a clearing. The transition was abrupt, as if the trees had parted just for them. In the center of the clearing stood a small brick house, quaint and unassuming, its white bricks standing in stark contrast to the wild greenery surrounding it. The house seemed oddly out of place, like a piece of civilization that had been plucked from another world and dropped into the heart of the forest.

The wizard approached the house without a word and stepped inside, leaving the door open behind him. Sidian hesitated at the threshold, a feeling of unease prickling at the back of their mind. But the open door felt like an invitation, and curiosity, once again, got the better of them. Sidian took a deep breath and stepped inside.

The interior of the house was as simple as its exterior. The room was small, with a single wooden table and two chairs set in the center. The table was bare, save for a chessboard that sat between the chairs, its pieces neatly aligned just as they had been in the book. The board seemed to glow with a faint, otherworldly light, as if it held a power far greater than its humble appearance suggested.

The wizard, now seated, gestured for Sidian to take the opposite chair. Sidian obliged, the tension in the air thickening with each passing moment. The wizard’s gaze was intense, piercing through the shadows that played across his face. Finally, after what felt like an eternity, the wizard began to speak, his voice low and resonant, filled with an ancient wisdom that made the very walls of the house seem to listen.

panel-1.panelText: Let’s introduce some basic pieces. Sliders are pieces that move in a straight line… any number of squares unless it’s blocked by something.

panel-2.panelText: This is the Rook, a major piece worth 5 points of material. It moves orthogonally: up, right, left down. Try capturing some pieces.

panel-3.panelText: The slider mechanic allows for tactical pins, skewers, and x-rays to happen… we'll go over those later.

panel-4.panelText: This is the Bishop, a minor piece worth 3 points. It moves in any diagonal direction. Try it out now. Do you notice anything about what squares it can move to?

panel-5.panelText: That's right! It is restricted to only one color complex. It can never land on an opposite color. Some of these Pawns are unable to be captured by the Bishop.

panel-6.panelText: The “Bishop pair” is a common advantage where if you happen to hang onto both of your Bishops and your opponent doesn’t then you have better influence over both color complexes.

lesson-5.title: Pawns I
lesson-5.nodeText: Learn about the backbone of every army... the Pawn.
lesson-5.panelText:
Sidian, now seated across from the wizard at the small table, felt the weight of silence hanging in the air. The wizard's intense gaze seemed to pierce through them, filling the room with an almost tangible tension. Gathering their courage, Sidian broke the silence.

"Who are you? And where are we?" Sidian's voice was steady, though a trace of uncertainty lingered in the question.

The wizard, however, did not bother with introductions. He remained silent for a moment, his eyes narrowing slightly as if considering how much to reveal. Finally, in a voice that seemed to carry the weight of countless years, he began to speak.

"This forest," the wizard said, his voice low and resonant, "is cursed. I have been trapped here for longer than I can remember—years, perhaps even decades. Time loses its meaning in a place like this." His gaze drifted toward the window, where the forest loomed just beyond the glass. "I've wandered these woods endlessly, searching for a way out. There are times when I come across a town, a glimpse of civilization. But when I leave and try to return... it's never the same. The town shifts, changes, as if it exists only in fragments. The people, the buildings—they're different every time, as if the forest itself is playing tricks on me."

The wizard paused, his expression darkening as he continued. "The only constant in this cursed place is the forest itself. No matter how far I wander, the trees are always there, watching, waiting."

Sidian listened intently, a shiver running down their spine. The wizard's words painted a picture of a place that defied logic, a realm where reality bent and twisted like the branches of the ancient trees outside.

"Is there any way to leave?" Sidian asked, their voice tinged with both hope and fear.

The wizard's gaze returned to Sidian, his eyes narrowing slightly. "There is a way," he said slowly, "but it is not easily earned. If you wish to leave this forest, you must defeat me in a game of Chess."

Sidian's eyes widened in surprise. "A game of Chess?"

The wizard nodded, his expression unreadable. "Yes. Chess is more than just a game. It is a test of the mind, a battle of wits. If you can best me, then perhaps you have the strength to break free from this cursed place."

With a mix of determination and trepidation, Sidian agreed. The wizard moved the pieces with a practiced hand, his movements precise and calculated. Sidian, however, quickly found themselves lost in the complexities of the game. The board seemed to blur before their eyes, the pieces moving with a life of their own, as if the game itself was an extension of the forest's mysterious power.

The wizard's moves were swift, his strategy impeccable, while Sidian struggled to keep up, their mind racing to make sense of the shifting patterns on the board. The game was unlike any Sidian had played before—every move felt heavy with consequence, as if the fate of more than just the game rested in their hands.

panel-1.panelText: Pawns are the soul of Chess. They are worth 1 point of material… but don’t underestimate them or treat them as expendable. They work together well in chains and in supporting outposts for minor pieces. Be mindful of how you trade off because they can be vulnerable without an adjacent pawn friend to protect them.

panel-2.panelText: Try moving this pawn now, notice how you have the option to move 2 squares forward on your first turn, but only 1 after that. Take a look at their capture pattern as well, diagonally and forward. Pawns cannot move backwards

panel-3.panelText: There are two special moves to be aware of with pawns, pay attention to this sequence, there is only one condition where this special move can take place:

panel-4.panelText: The black Pawn moves to the 3rd rank (or 5th for white).

panel-5.panelText: The white Pawn moves two squares forward.

panel-6.panelText: Here’s the trick, black has the option to move the Pawn forward. BUT, the condition is now correct for “En Passant” to take place, so black is also able to capture that white Pawn by landing on the square behind it. It must happen immediately after the victim Pawn moves the 2 squares up or else the condition will no longer exist until another takes place. This is a rule is in place to help prevent locked up, boring positions.

panel-7.panelText: The Pawn’s other special ability: when it reaches the last rank, it can “promote” and change into any other piece besides a King. We can call this a “sub-objective” of the game. In a lot of the scenarios when a promotion happens, it can be game-ending.

panel-8.panelText: The Pawn’s other special ability: when it reaches the last rank, it can “promote” and change into any other piece besides a King. We can call this a “sub-objective” of the game. In a lot of the scenarios when a promotion happens, it can be game-ending.

lesson-6.title: Into the Meta
lesson-6.nodeText: Learn about curiosity, the framework behind your thinking during a game.
lesson-6.panelText:
The wizard paused, reaching for a mug that sat on the edge of the table. He took a slow, deliberate sip, his eyes never leaving the chessboard. The faint clinking of the mug as he set it back down was the only sound in the room, a subtle reminder of the stillness that surrounded them. Sidian watched him, waiting for the wizard to speak.

"The game of Chess," the wizard began, his voice steady and measured, "is more than just a battle of pieces on a board. It is a game of information, of knowledge. Curiosity is your greatest ally. The more you know about your opponent, the better you can predict their moves. You must observe, analyze, and anticipate. Every piece, every move, tells a story."

Sidian listened intently as the wizard continued. "But it’s not just about your opponent. The more you know about the game itself—the strategies, the patterns, the possibilities—the better you can predict the outcome. And perhaps most importantly, the more you know about yourself, the better you can predict your own moves. Self-awareness is key. You must understand your strengths and weaknesses, your tendencies, your impulses."

There was a depth to the wizard’s words that resonated with Sidian. It was as though he was not just talking about Chess, but about life itself. The game was a mirror, reflecting the complexities and challenges of existence. Sidian felt a newfound respect for the wizard and the wisdom he imparted.

After a moment of contemplation, Sidian stood, ready to leave. But just as they turned to go, the wizard's voice halted them in their tracks.

"Wait," the wizard said, his tone suddenly more serious. "There is something else you should know. A legend, passed down through generations. It speaks of talismans—powerful objects that can alter the course of fate. They are hidden deep within this forest, but they are rare, elusive. Some say they may even exist beyond the forest, if such a place truly exists."

Sidian turned back to face the wizard, intrigued by this new revelation. The wizard reached into the folds of his robes and produced a small, intricately carved talisman. It was unlike anything Sidian had seen before, glowing faintly with an ethereal light. The symbols etched into its surface seemed to pulse with a life of their own, as if holding some ancient power.

"I’ve kept this talisman safe for many years," the wizard said, handing it to Sidian. "It is said to hold great power, though its true potential can only be unlocked by those who possess the will and the wisdom to wield it. Take it. It may guide you in ways you do not yet understand."

Sidian accepted the talisman, feeling its weight in their hand. There was something comforting about it, a warmth that contrasted with the coldness of the forest outside. The wizard’s words echoed in Sidian’s mind—curiosity, knowledge, self-awareness. Perhaps this talisman was a key to unlocking all of those things.

But before Sidian could leave, the wizard’s eyes gleamed with a challenge. "One more game," he proposed, his voice carrying a note of anticipation. "This time, let me show you the power of the talisman."

Reluctantly, Sidian agreed, curiosity once again getting the better of them. They sat back down at the table, and the wizard began to arrange the pieces on the board. As the game commenced, the wizard placed the talisman in the center of the board. To Sidian's astonishment, the talisman began to glow brighter, and the pieces seemed to move with a will of their own, guided by the mysterious power of the artifact.

The wizard demonstrated the talisman’s influence, showing how it could bend the rules of the game, alter probabilities, and change the course of the match. Sidian was mesmerized, realizing that the talisman was more than just a trinket—it was a powerful tool, capable of reshaping reality itself.

The game took on a new dimension, one where the lines between strategy and magic blurred. Every move was infused with the talisman’s energy, making the stakes feel higher, the consequences more profound. Sidian could feel the weight of the forest, the curse, and the wizard’s wisdom all converging on this singular moment, with the talisman at the heart of it all.

panel-1.panelText: A critical skill to help begin your journey in Chess is communication. Ask yourself the important questions. Start with inquires like: “What story is being told in this position?”, or “Why did I just play that move?”. Be observational.

panel-2.panelText: Prompts like these will help you search for meaning in the position, organize your thinking, and hydrate your plans. We’ll touch on plans and more helpful questions later.

panel-3.panelText: Let’s look at the Equus family. The Knight is recognized as apart of the normal variation of Chess. It moves 2 squares orthogonally then 1 square perpendicular. Think in the shape of an L. Watch out for Knights, they are tricky and can hop over other pieces. Try moving it now.

panel-4.panelText: This is the Zebra. It is confined to a singular color complex like the bishop. Think in the same shape of the King, but diagonally… and hops over pieces as well. This is the more predictable of the Equus pieces.

panel-5.panelText: Finally, the Unicorn. A new tricky piece that can target the first move of a Rook, or to the second square that a Bishop. It hops other pieces similar to it's sisters. Think teleporting to engage in close combat!

panel-6.panelText: You’ll have to spend some time with these pieces and understand their tactics, don’t underestimate them in closed positions!

temple-1.title: Temple of Singularities I
temple-1.nodeText: Play through one-move puzzles to test your knowledge of the pieces.
temple-1.panelText:
Sidian stepped cautiously into the overgrown temple, the ancient structure almost swallowed by the encroaching wilderness. Vines and moss clung to the weathered stones, and the air was thick with the scent of damp earth and decaying leaves. As they moved deeper into the temple, the faint sound of rustling leaves filled the air, as though the very trees surrounding the temple were whispering secrets, their voices carried by the gentle breeze that barely stirred the dense foliage.

The atmosphere was heavy with an otherworldly presence. Spectral owls, their ghostly forms barely distinguishable from the shadows, watched Sidian from their perches high in the temple's rafters. Their eyes glowed with an eerie, ethereal light, a mixture of ancient wisdom and a silent warning. The owls remained motionless, their gaze unblinking, as if waiting for something—or someone.

Suddenly, one of the owls broke from the shadows, swooping down with a graceful, silent flight. It landed with a soft thud on a stone pedestal at the center of the temple, its presence commanding the room. Though its beak remained closed, Sidian could hear a voice—calm yet imposing—echoing in their mind.

"The tree's roots run deep, but which path will make it weep?"

The riddle hung in the air, its meaning elusive and profound. Sidian’s mind raced, trying to decipher the cryptic message. The temple seemed to hum with anticipation, as if the very stones were alive, waiting for Sidian to solve the puzzle.

In response to the riddle, a magical chessboard materialized before them, hovering slightly above the ground. The board was unlike any Sidian had seen before, its squares glowing faintly, the pieces translucent and shimmering with a soft inner light. It was as if the game itself was infused with the very essence of the temple, ancient and mysterious.

Sidian felt a connection to the board, not through touch, but through their mind. The bond was immediate and profound, as if the board was an extension of their thoughts, responding to their very will. Sidian’s focus sharpened, and in an instant, the first answer to the riddle revealed itself.

The pieces on the chessboard shifted and morphed, rearranging themselves into a new position. The movement was fluid, almost organic, as if the pieces were alive, responding to the ancient riddle’s hidden logic. Sidian could sense that the game was more than just a test of strategy—it was a key, unlocking a deeper truth buried within the temple’s ancient walls.

The temple grew quieter, the rustling leaves now a distant memory. The spectral owls watched in silence, their glowing eyes fixed on Sidian, waiting to see if they would find the correct path, the one that would make the tree weep.

temple-4.title: Temple of Singularities II
temple-4.nodeText: Play through one-move puzzles to test your knowledge of the pieces.
temple-4.panelText:
"We have only just begun."

The voice echoed in Sidian's mind, carrying with it a weight of ominous promise. The temple, once faintly lit by the waning daylight, was now plunged into darkness, as if the very light had been swallowed by the encroaching shadows. Sidian nodded, steeling themselves for what was to come, a sense of foreboding settling deep within their chest.

Around the edge of the clearing, the darkness twisted and churned, and from it emerged shapes—vague at first, but quickly taking form. Demons, their grotesque figures illuminated by an unnatural, flickering light, began to dance at the periphery, their movements erratic and mocking. Their eyes glowed with malice, and their twisted faces contorted into sneers as they jeered and taunted Sidian, their voices a cacophony of derision.

The demons' dance was chaotic, their limbs flailing and twisting in unnatural ways as they circled the clearing, trying to break Sidian’s concentration. Their laughter was sharp, cutting through the air like a knife, each jeer designed to unnerve and distract. But Sidian remained focused, their gaze fixed on the magical chessboard that still hovered before them.

The voice returned, calm and steady, cutting through the chaos with its cryptic riddle. "In the tree's shade, shadows dance, but which piece leads the trance?"

The riddle hung heavy in the air, its meaning obscured by the darkness that pressed in from all sides. The demons’ dance seemed to intensify, their movements growing wilder, as if they were feeding off the uncertainty in Sidian's mind. The chessboard, now glowing brighter in the surrounding gloom, seemed to pulse in time with the demonic rhythm, its pieces waiting for Sidian’s next move.

Sidian’s mind raced as they tried to unravel the riddle’s meaning. The shadows danced in the tree's shade—was it a metaphor? Or was it something more literal? And which piece—what could it signify? The question weighed heavily on Sidian, as if the very fate of the forest hinged on their ability to find the answer.

The demons continued their torment, their voices growing louder, more insistent, but Sidian blocked them out, focusing entirely on the board. The answer was there, somewhere, hidden in the depths of the game and the riddle’s words. Slowly, Sidian began to see the patterns emerge, the connections between the pieces and the shadows that danced around them.

Then, it came to them—like a flash of insight piercing through the darkness. The piece that leads the trance, the one that moves in the shadows, the one that guides the dance. Sidian reached out with their mind, moving the piece into place with deliberate care. The board responded, the pieces shifting and realigning as the riddle’s answer took form.

The moment the move was completed, the demons recoiled, their laughter turning into shrieks of frustration. The darkness seemed to falter, the oppressive weight of it lifting just slightly. But Sidian knew that this was only the beginning—the game was far from over.

temple-2.title: Temple of Binaries I
temple-2.nodeText: Play through two-move puzzles to further test your knowledge of the pieces.
temple-2.panelText:
The pieces on the board shimmered for a moment before vanishing completely, dissolving into the air like wisps of smoke. The chessboard, once vibrant with the energy of the game, now lay empty, a silent testament to the puzzle Sidian had just solved. A sense of accomplishment washed over them, but it was fleeting, quickly replaced by the awareness that this was only one step in a much larger challenge.

Sidian lifted their gaze, staring upward at the thick canopy of trees that loomed overhead. The leaves rustled softly, as if whispering secrets to one another, their movements barely perceptible in the dim light that filtered through. The sky beyond the canopy was a patchwork of deep blues and purples, the day inching toward dusk, casting long shadows that seemed to dance with a life of their own.

Then, the voice returned, its tone as enigmatic as ever, weaving another riddle that sent a shiver down Sidian's spine.

"The tree's branches reach high, but which path will make it sigh? In the dance of binaries, where the twin shadows play, the path forward lies where the light splits the day. Seek the singular mate, where one becomes two, and the answer will guide you true."

The riddle hung in the air, its meaning elusive yet tantalizingly close. Sidian’s mind raced to interpret the cryptic words. The tree's branches reaching high—did it symbolize growth or something else? The path that would make it sigh—was it a metaphor for sorrow or perhaps something more abstract, like the end of a journey?

The mention of binaries, twin shadows, and light splitting the day added layers of complexity. The "dance of binaries" suggested opposites, pairs, or perhaps even a choice between two paths. The "twin shadows" seemed to echo this duality, playing in the light and darkness, challenging Sidian to discern the true path.

But it was the final part of the riddle that struck Sidian the most—"Seek the singular mate, where one becomes two." Chess flashed through Sidian's mind again, a game of pairs, of moves and counter-moves, where each piece has a counterpart. But this was something deeper, something tied to the very essence of the riddle.

The temple grew quieter, the rustling of the leaves fading into the background as Sidian pondered the meaning of the words. The answer, they knew, lay in the understanding of this riddle, in deciphering the interplay of light and shadow, in finding the path where one could become two.

Sidian took a deep breath, feeling the weight of the riddle pressing down on them. They knew that the answer would not only guide them forward but also reveal more of the mystery that surrounded this ancient, enigmatic place. The journey was far from over, and the next step was shrouded in the same darkness that now crept ever closer as the day continued its slow descent into night.

temple-5.title: Temple of Binaries II
temple-5.nodeText: Play through two-move puzzles to further test your knowledge of the pieces.
temple-5.panelText:
The guardian owl, perched high above on a twisted branch, watched Sidian with a gaze that seemed to carry both wisdom and warmth. Its glowing eyes, once intense and unreadable, now softened, as if in approval of the progress Sidian had made. A sense of friendly praise emanated from the owl, a silent acknowledgment of Sidian's determination and growing understanding.

Then, the familiar voice echoed in Sidian’s mind once more, its tone resonant and filled with the weight of ancient knowledge.

"In the dance of binaries, where truth and lies entwine, two paths diverge, yet only one reveals the sign. Seek the mate where shadow and light converge, for when reflection turns real, the tree shall emerge."

The riddle wove itself into the fabric of Sidian’s thoughts, the words sinking deep into their consciousness. The dance of binaries—truth and lies—suggested a world of dualities, of choices that might seem clear but were, in reality, far more complex. Two paths lay ahead, but only one held the truth, the sign that would guide them forward.

Sidian’s mind raced to decipher the meaning behind the convergence of shadow and light. The image of a place where opposites meet, where the boundary between darkness and illumination blurs, began to take shape in their thoughts. It was there, in that liminal space, that the answer would be found.

But the riddle went further, hinting at something even more profound. "When reflection turns real," it said, suggesting a moment of revelation, where what is seen as merely a reflection—a shadow, a mirage—would become tangible, solid, real. This transformation, this convergence, would bring forth the tree, the very heart of the mystery that Sidian was unraveling.

The owl’s gaze remained fixed on Sidian, its presence a comforting reminder that they were not alone in this journey. The temple, now a silent witness to the unfolding of these riddles, seemed to hold its breath, waiting for Sidian to take the next step.

Sidian felt a renewed sense of determination. The path forward was shrouded in uncertainty, yet the clues were there, hidden within the riddles, waiting to be discovered. The guardian owl had offered its silent praise, and the voice had provided the guidance needed. Now, it was up to Sidian to find the place where shadow and light converged, where reflection would become reality, and where the tree, the key to it all, would finally emerge.

The journey was far from over, but with each riddle solved, Sidian felt closer to unlocking the ancient secrets of the forest, guided by the wisdom of the owl and the enigmatic voice that echoed in their mind.

temple-3.title: Temple of Singularity Mates I
temple-3.panelText:
The owl, perched gracefully on its branch, beckoned Sidian forward with a slow, deliberate motion of its wing. Its glowing eyes, now filled with a mixture of amusement and expectation, seemed to twinkle in the dim light filtering through the dense canopy above. Sidian, feeling a curious blend of anticipation and trepidation, followed the owl’s silent command, stepping cautiously along the narrow path that unfurled before them.

As Sidian walked, the path seemed to twist and wind in on itself, the forest growing denser with each step. The trees, ancient and towering, loomed overhead, their branches intertwining to form a near-impenetrable ceiling. The air was thick with the scent of earth and moss, and the only sounds were the faint rustling of leaves and the soft crunch of twigs beneath Sidian’s feet. The sense of déjà vu was palpable, as if they had walked this path before, perhaps many times.

After what felt like an eternity, the path led Sidian back to a familiar sight—the owl’s temple. The realization struck Sidian like a wave; they had returned to where they started, the path having led them in a circle. The temple stood silent and imposing, its weathered stones cloaked in shadows, as if the forest itself had drawn them back to this place.

The owl, still perched on its branch, let out a soft, melodic chuckle that echoed through the clearing. There was a knowing look in its eyes, as if it had expected this all along. It motioned with its wing towards the center of the temple, where the magical chessboard had once again materialized, its ethereal glow casting a faint light on the ancient stones.

As Sidian approached the board, the owl’s voice resonated in their mind, the words carrying a weight of both warning and wisdom.

"In the depths where binaries fade, a singular mate remains unmade. Choose the path where time stands still, but know this choice is not the tree's will."

The riddle was as cryptic as ever, its meaning buried beneath layers of metaphor and enigma. Sidian pondered the words, trying to make sense of them. The idea of binaries fading suggested a place beyond dualities, where opposites ceased to exist. A singular mate remaining unmade hinted at an unfinished task, a choice yet to be made. But the true challenge lay in the next line—choosing a path where time stood still, a path that was against the will of the tree itself.

The shadows between the trees seemed to come alive, flickering and shifting as if taunting Sidian, daring them to solve the puzzle that lay before them. The forest, with all its mysteries and riddles, felt like a living entity, its will entwined with the very fabric of the game.

Sidian took a deep breath and focused on the board, feeling the familiar connection form once again. The pieces shimmered and shifted under the influence of their thoughts, awaiting the next move. But this time, the decision felt more significant, the stakes higher. The riddle had warned that the choice would go against the tree’s will—what could that mean?

As Sidian moved the pieces, the shadows danced around the edges of their vision, teasing and distracting, but Sidian remained resolute. The path forward was unclear, yet the riddle’s words echoed in their mind, guiding their hand. The chessboard, with its timeless game, was more than just a puzzle—it was a test, a gateway to understanding the deeper mysteries of the forest.

Sidian made the move, the singular mate remaining unmade, the path chosen. The forest held its breath, as if waiting to see what would come of this choice, the air thick with the anticipation of what lay ahead.

temple-6.title: Temple of Singularity Mates II
temple-6.panelText:
The shadows, which had been teasing Sidian from the periphery, suddenly grew more aggressive. Their forms twisted and contorted, lashing out with an intensity that shook the very ground beneath Sidian’s feet. Branches and rocks, seemingly animated by the shadows' malevolent will, flew through the air, hurtling towards Sidian in a chaotic flurry. But even as the onslaught began, the chessboard before Sidian gleamed brightly, a radiant light signifying victory. The pieces had settled into place, and the riddle had been solved.

Amidst the turmoil, the guardian owl’s voice echoed through Sidian’s mind, its tone calm and reassuring, cutting through the clamor of the shadows.

"Pay them no mind. They are tormented souls from a realm of endless frustration. Their burdens are not for you to bear. We each walk our own path, and sometimes we are alone on that path. That does not make it incorrect."

The owl’s words resonated deeply within Sidian, offering both comfort and wisdom. The shadows, with all their rage and despair, were but echoes of those who had failed to find their way, lost in a cycle of frustration and regret. Their attempts to disrupt Sidian were born from their own torment, but the owl reminded Sidian that these burdens were not theirs to carry. The path Sidian walked was their own, unique and necessary, even if it sometimes felt solitary.

As the shadows continued their futile assault, the owl’s voice spoke again, this time with a note of finality.

"Solve this last puzzle, and the correct path will open before you."

Sidian felt the weight of those words. This was the final challenge, the culmination of all the riddles and trials they had faced. The shadows, though fierce and unrelenting, were but a distraction, a test of focus and resolve. The key to the correct path lay not in the external chaos, but in the calm center that Sidian could maintain within themselves.

The chessboard, still glowing with the light of victory, shimmered once more, signaling the arrival of the last puzzle. Sidian could feel the pieces moving, rearranging themselves into a new, more complex configuration. The stakes were higher now, the pressure more intense, but the owl’s words lingered in Sidian’s mind, offering guidance and strength.

Taking a deep breath, Sidian tuned out the noise of the shadows, their mind honing in on the board before them. The final puzzle awaited, and with it, the promise of the correct path—the path that would lead Sidian forward, beyond the trials of the forest and into the heart of the unknown.

The air around Sidian seemed to still, the world narrowing to just the board and the puzzle that needed solving. The shadows’ attacks faded into the background, mere whispers against the steady rhythm of Sidian’s thoughts. The owl’s gaze remained steady, a silent sentinel watching over the final challenge.

With renewed focus, Sidian began to solve the puzzle, each move bringing them closer to unlocking the path that lay just beyond the reach of the shadows, a path illuminated by the light of their own perseverance and determination.

mission-1.title: The Cutoff
mission-1.panelText:
Sidian emerged from the wizard's house, feeling the cool air of the forest brush against their skin. The world outside felt different, almost as if it had rearranged itself while they were inside. Indeed, as Sidian looked around, the trailhead that had once led them here had shifted into a new configuration, the path now winding in unfamiliar directions. Despite the uncertainty, Sidian felt a surge of eagerness. Whatever the next challenge would be, they were ready to face it.

With a determined step, Sidian began to follow the new path. The forest around them seemed alive, the trees whispering secrets with every rustle of leaves, the shadows dancing in the corners of their vision. The path twisted and turned, leading Sidian through a maze of towering trees and overgrown underbrush. The air was thick with the scent of pine and earth, grounding Sidian in the reality of this strange, ever-changing world.

Before long, after navigating the winding trail, Sidian found themselves standing at the edge of a bustling town. The sudden shift from the quiet, mysterious forest to the lively, chaotic energy of the town was jarring. The streets were filled with people going about their daily lives, vendors calling out their wares, children running and playing, and the sound of conversation filling the air. It was as if this town had been untouched by the strange forces that governed the forest.

Sidian’s eyes were drawn to a nearby tavern, its wooden sign creaking in the breeze. The warm glow of light spilled out from its windows, and the sound of laughter and clinking mugs beckoned them inside. Curious and in need of a rest, Sidian decided to enter.

The tavern was dimly lit, the atmosphere thick with the scent of ale and roasting meat. As Sidian’s eyes adjusted to the darkness, they noticed that many of the patrons were cloaked figures, their faces hidden in shadow. The room buzzed with quiet conversation, the clatter of dishes, and the occasional burst of laughter. Despite the tavern’s lively air, there was an underlying tension, as if something was waiting just beneath the surface.

As Sidian scanned the room, a table in the far corner caught their eye. Seated there was a solitary figure, hunched over a chessboard. The figure’s hood obscured their face, but there was something about them that drew Sidian’s attention, a sense of quiet intensity that set them apart from the other patrons.

Intrigued, Sidian approached the bartender, a burly man with a grizzled beard and a no-nonsense demeanor. “Who is that?” Sidian asked, nodding towards the figure at the chessboard.

The bartender followed Sidian’s gaze, his expression darkening slightly. “That’s one of the ephilates,” he said in a low voice, almost as if the words themselves carried a weight of sorrow. “Stuck wandering the forest for eternity. They say their life force was stolen from them long ago by playing against a mystical being. Now, they’re trapped, endlessly repeating the same moves, searching for something they’ll never find.”

The bartender’s words hung in the air, heavy with a sense of doom. Sidian felt a shiver run down their spine, the story of the ephilate a grim reminder of the forest’s darker side. Everything in Sidian’s mind screamed to stay away, to leave the tavern and continue on their journey. But something else—a deeper curiosity, perhaps—compelled Sidian to approach the table.

Against their better judgment, Sidian walked over to the corner where the ephilate sat. The figure didn’t look up as Sidian approached, their focus entirely on the board before them. The pieces were arranged in a complex pattern, one that Sidian recognized as a game in progress but with a configuration that seemed strange, almost impossible.

Sidian hesitated for a moment, then spoke, their voice steady despite the growing unease. “I’d like to challenge you to a game of chess.”

The ephilate slowly lifted their head, revealing a pale, gaunt face marked by years of sorrow and loss. Their eyes, hollow and dark, bore the weight of endless suffering. For a moment, they simply stared at Sidian, as if weighing the decision. Then, with a slow, deliberate nod, they gestured to the empty chair across from them.

Sidian sat down, the sense of foreboding growing stronger, but it was too late to turn back now. The game was about to begin, and with it, the next chapter of Sidian’s journey—one that would delve even deeper into the mysteries of the forest and the fate of those who had become lost within its grasp.

mission-2.title: A Pair and a Trickster
mission-2.panelText:
The ephilate’s hollow eyes met Sidian’s, and with a slow, deliberate nod, the spectral figure asked for another challenge. Sidian, already feeling the weight of the encounter and eager to leave the eerie tavern, hesitated. “I think I should be going,” Sidian began, their voice betraying a hint of nervousness. But the ephilate insisted, their tone carrying an unsettling urgency.

Sidian didn’t want to appear rude or disrespectful, especially in a place as strange and charged with energy as this. Reluctantly, and against their better judgment, they agreed to another game. Almost immediately, the atmosphere in the room shifted. The lively murmur of conversation, the clinking of mugs, the warm glow of the tavern—all of it vanished in an instant, replaced by an oppressive darkness that seemed to seep in from the corners of the room.

The air grew cold, and Sidian felt a chill run down their spine. They glanced around, only to see that all the patrons in the tavern had frozen in place, their movements halted as if time itself had stopped. The only thing that moved was the ephilate, whose eyes now glowed with a sinister, unnatural light. The once-muted glow had turned malevolent, casting eerie shadows across the walls.

Before Sidian could react, the chess pieces on the board began to move on their own, resetting themselves to the starting position. The board shimmered with an ominous light, as if infused with the same dark energy that now permeated the room. Sidian’s heart pounded in their chest, the realization dawning on them that something far more dangerous than a simple game was at play.

A voice, deep and echoing, reverberated through Sidian’s mind, sending a shiver through their very soul. “You have been tricked, Sidian. You will play me again, but this time, if you win I will leave you with a great gift. If you lose, however, I will take your life force, so that I may not wander this forest forever.”

The words carried a dreadful finality, the weight of a fate that had been sealed the moment Sidian had agreed to the second game. The ephilate’s gaze bore into Sidian, its eyes glowing brighter, filled with a hunger that had been denied for centuries. The once-tavern had transformed into a trap, the walls seeming to close in around them, leaving Sidian with no escape.

Sidian was trapped, the only way out now lying through the board that gleamed ominously between them. The stakes had escalated beyond mere curiosity or a test of skill—this was now a battle for survival, a game where the cost of losing was far more than just defeat. The air felt heavy, laden with the promise of doom, as the ephilate leaned forward, ready to begin.

The room was deathly silent, save for the faint rustling of the chess pieces as they settled into place. Sidian took a deep breath, forcing themselves to focus, to push aside the fear that threatened to paralyze them. The game was their only hope now. Win, and they might escape with something valuable, a gift promised by the eerie voice. Lose, and their life would be forfeit, their essence consumed by the malevolent being across the table.

Sidian’s hands trembled slightly as they reached for the first piece, the cold weight of it grounding them in the moment. The ephilate waited, patient and predatory, its gaze never wavering. The first move was made, and the game began anew, the tension in the room coiling tighter with each passing second. Sidian knew that every decision, every move, would bring them closer to either victory or a fate worse than death.

The shadows in the room seemed to pulse with a life of their own, watching, waiting, eager to see which way the game would turn. Sidian steeled themselves, knowing that this would be the most important game of their life, one that would determine not just their future, but their very existence.

mission-3.title: Fair is Fair
mission-3.panelText:
Sidian left the tavern and soon encountered a peddler on the forest path. After purchasing some goods, the peddler, as a token of gratitude, reached into his pocket and handed Sidian a talisman. The peddler admitted he didn’t know what it did and preferred to stay away from magic. He also shared a rumor: there was a tree deep in the forest that controlled the entire woodland. It was said that a grandmaster once tried to break the tree’s curse but never returned. Some believed he lost an epic game and was forced to merge with the tree.

With the new talisman in hand, Sidian decided to venture deeper into the forest. After some time, he found a clearing with a chessboard in the center, the pieces set up in a peculiar pattern. Curious, Sidian approached to study the position. But just as he leaned in, a rope suddenly sprang from a bush, wrapping tightly around his legs, pulling him off his feet.

A hunter emerged from the bush, a sly grin on his face. He challenged Sidian to a game of chess, the winner walking away with the other’s inventory. Sidian, trapped and with little choice, prepared for another game, knowing the stakes were higher than ever.

mission-4.title: Up the Exchange
mission-4.panelText:
The moment Sidian revealed the talisman, the hunter's eyes widened with intrigue. Sensing an opportunity, the hunter quickly proposed a game with the talisman on the line. Sidian, still bound by the hunter’s trap, realized there was little choice but to agree. The hunter’s grin widened as he reached into his pocket, pulling out a talisman of his own. With a swift motion of his hand, the pieces on the chessboard rearranged themselves into a new, more challenging configuration.

The hunter, confident in his abilities, stated that Sidian might have the advantage this time, but there would be no reward for winning. If the hunter won despite the disadvantage, he would claim the talisman as his prize. The air grew tense as the hunter’s talisman glowed faintly, and he began to control his pieces from a distance, using only his mind.

Sidian, feeling the weight of the challenge, focused intently on the board. The hunter’s talisman added an extra layer of difficulty, as the pieces seemed to move with a life of their own. Each move carried the possibility of victory or loss, and Sidian knew that this game was far more than a simple contest—it was a battle of wills, with the talismans amplifying the stakes.

The game continued, each move more intense than the last. The hunter’s confidence was palpable, his smirk never fading as he effortlessly manipulated the board. Sidian, however, remained determined, knowing that he had to outthink the hunter if he was to keep the talisman and escape the hunter's grasp.

mission-5.title: Mythic Safari
mission-5.panelText:
Sidian left the town without speaking to anyone and ventured deep into the forest. The paths became increasingly obfuscated and winding, leading Sidian back to where they started. The town was lost, seemingly vanished into the dense, twisting woods.

Hours seemed to pass as Sidian pressed further into the forest, following a dark, narrow path. Suddenly, a ghostly figure appeared before them—another ephilate, like the one encountered in the tavern. With a sinister grin, the ephilate challenged Sidian to a game of chess. Sidian, now equipped with a new talisman, accepted the challenge.

As darkness deepened around them, a magical visualization of a chessboard materialized between them. The ephilate, eyes gleaming with malice, once again bargained for Sidian's life force. Knowing that the only way to escape the encroaching darkness was to win, Sidian steeled their nerves and made the first move.

The forest seemed to hold its breath as the game began. Sidian knew that this battle, more than any before, would determine their fate in the treacherous forest.

mission-6.title: An Uncertain Imbalance

diagWinLose.victory: The ephilate falls to the ground and evaporates into the darkness. Sidian continues through the forest in hopes of find the tree and rescuing the inhabitants of the forest.

mission-6.panelText:
The ephilate, visibly frustrated by its loss, concentrated intensely to keep the darkness from lifting. Its eyes glowed with malevolent energy as it began to chant a summoning spell. In response, two talismans materialized in its hands, their dark energy pulsing ominously.

Sidian, sensing the danger, attempted to access the power of their own talisman, willing the darkness to lift. They focused all their energy, forcing their will upon the oppressive shadows, but to no avail. The darkness remained, thick and unyielding, as if feeding off the ephilate's malevolent intent.

With no hope of escape and the weight of the situation pressing down on them, Sidian realized there was only one option left. They would have to play the ephilate again, knowing that the stakes were now even higher.

mission-7.title: Accelerate

diagWinLose.defeat: Roots erupt from the ground and wrap around Sidian's limbs. They try to break free but your body is shocked with fear. The tree laughs as they are brought to your knees. The roots dragging Sidian below the ground is the last thing that they remember. Suddenly, they are awake again, lost in the forest.

mission-7.panelText:
The owl congratulated Sidian for solving the final riddle of the maze, its voice filled with a rare warmth. With a graceful nod, the owl granted Sidian passage from the temple, and the forest responded in kind. The trees shifted, and a new path opened before Sidian, beckoning them forward.

Sidian walked through a short series of winding, mystical paths, each one filled with an ethereal sense of wonder. The air seemed to hum with ancient energy, guiding them deeper into the heart of the forest. Eventually, Sidian emerged into a wide clearing, where a massive silhouette loomed in the distance. It was the tree—the very one that controlled the entire forest. Its massive trunk was adorned with a giant arm growing from its side, adding to its menacing presence.

A deep, resonant voice echoed through the clearing. "It's been awhile since I've had any victims wander into my domain," the tree rumbled. "I'm looking forward to more energy to add to my forest. Especially after that annoying wizard gave me a hard time. I made easy work of him with my disillusionment charm, and now he'll wander forever, as will you."

mission-8.title: Hostile Reinforcements

diagWinLose.victory:
The tree gasps in shock as the roots around it shrink and wither. It's arm reaches out to Sidian but fails.

"You shall join me in peril"

 It begins to conjure a dark spell to connect with Sidian's life force. Sidian in turn connects with their talismen and blocks the spell. The tree topples over and the forest begins to return to normal.
diagWinLose.defeat: Roots erupt from the ground and wrap around Sidian's limbs. They try to break free but your body is shocked with fear. The tree laughs as they are brought to your knees. The roots dragging Sidian below the ground is the last thing that they remember. Suddenly, they are awake again, lost in the forest.

mission-8.panelText:
The tree, sensing its imminent defeat, began to recover, though its roots withered around its base. Desperate, it tried to bargain with Sidian. "If you stop now, I will spare you and grant you the power of the forest. Walk away, and you'll never have to see me again. The ephilates won’t bother you, and you may come and go as you please."

Sidian considered the offer, but thoughts of the wizard trapped for eternity and the town folk lost in the forest weighed heavily on their mind. Sidian knew that defeating the tree was the only way to save the forest and free those trapped within it. Determined, Sidian grasped the talisman, focused their energy, and stood their ground. In response, the chessboard appeared once more, this time in a new, challenging configuration, as the roots around Sidian began to stir ominously.

The tree’s voice darkened with anger. "Very well, you will regret that decision. I shall make you one with the forest."
